# Bone Pathology Framework: AVN, Metabolic Disease, Osteomyelitis, Tumors
## Top-down map
```
Bone pathology
├── Vascular: avascular necrosis
├── Metabolic: osteoporosis, osteomalacia, Paget disease
├── Infection: osteomyelitis (site/context-specific)
└── Tumor: benign/malignant patterns by location and imaging
```

## Avascular necrosis (AVN)
- Typical true hip localization is groin pain with weight-bearing aggravation.
- Risk contexts: chronic steroids, heavy alcohol, trauma/sickle-cell microvascular injury, systemic inflammatory disease.
- Early X-ray can be normal; MRI is most sensitive for early disease.

## Metabolic bone disease split
| Feature | Osteoporosis | Osteomalacia |
| --- | --- | --- |
| Core defect | reduced bone mass | impaired mineralization |
| Typical labs | often near-normal routine calcium/phosphate | low vitamin D pattern with secondary hyperparathyroidism |
| Clinical pattern | fragility fracture risk | bone pain/proximal weakness/waddling gait |

## Paget disease essentials
- Disorganized remodeling with isolated high alkaline phosphatase pattern.
- Can present with skull enlargement/hearing changes and focal bone pain.
- Bisphosphonate-centered suppression is key therapy.

# Osteomyelitis and Bone Tumor Location Game
## Osteomyelitis by context
- Vertebral osteomyelitis: persistent focal spinal tenderness with MRI as key test; fever can be absent.
- Pediatric hematogenous osteomyelitis: metaphyseal preference; Staph aureus is common.
- Sickle-cell context: Salmonella is high-yield association.
- Diabetic foot: contiguous spread from ulcer; probe-to-bone is important bedside clue.
- Prosthetic joint infection timing:
| Timing from surgery | Typical microbial pattern |
| --- | --- |
| early (<3 months) | virulent organisms including Staph aureus/gram negatives |
| delayed (3-12 months) | coagulase-negative staphylococcal biofilm patterns |

## Bone tumors
- Osteoid osteoma: nocturnal pain relieved by NSAID.
- Osteosarcoma: metaphyseal aggressive lesion (sunburst/Codman patterns).
- Ewing sarcoma: diaphyseal small-round-blue-cell profile with onion-skin periosteal reaction.
- Giant-cell tumor: epiphyseal soap-bubble appearance in skeletally mature patients.
- Langerhans-cell spectrum can present with lytic lesions and systemic signs.

# Vasculitis and Myopathy/NMJ Classification
## Structural map
```
Vasculitis + myopathy/NMJ
├── Large-vessel vasculitis: GCA, Takayasu
├── Medium-vessel vasculitis: Kawasaki, PAN, Buerger
├── Small-vessel vasculitis: GPA, EGPA, IgA vasculitis, Behcet/cryoglobulinemic patterns
└── Muscle/NMJ disorders
    ├── Pain-dominant: PMR
    ├── Weakness-dominant: inflammatory myopathies
    └── NMJ disorders: MG vs Lambert-Eaton
```

## Pattern recognition rule
- Vessel size plus organ-territory involvement drives differential prioritization.
- For weakness complaints, separate pain-limited movement from true motor weakness before ordering expansive autoimmune panels.

# Large and Medium Vessel Vasculitis
## Giant cell arteritis (GCA)
- Typical older patient with headache/scalp tenderness and jaw claudication.
- Visual symptoms represent emergency due to ischemic optic risk.
- Start high-dose steroids immediately when vision-threatening features appear; do not wait for biopsy.
- Temporal artery biopsy confirms diagnosis; monitor for long-term aortic complications.
- PMR association is frequent.

## Takayasu arteritis
- Younger patient with pulse asymmetry/BP discrepancy and large-vessel inflammatory changes on imaging.

## Kawasaki disease
- Child with prolonged fever and mucocutaneous/inflammatory criteria.
- Major risk is coronary aneurysm; echocardiographic surveillance required.
- Treatment is IVIG plus aspirin despite usual pediatric aspirin cautions.

## PAN and Buerger
- PAN: medium-vessel multisystem ischemia pattern with pulmonary sparing and angiographic microaneurysm clues.
- Buerger: tobacco-linked distal ischemic disease; smoking cessation is core therapy.

# Small Vessel Vasculitis and ANCA Patterns
## GPA (granulomatosis with polyangiitis)
- ENT + lung + kidney triad pattern with c-ANCA/PR3 association.

## EGPA
- Asthma/eosinophilia with p-ANCA/MPO context and small-vessel inflammatory phenotype.

## IgA vasculitis (HSP)
- Pediatric palpable purpura (lower body), arthralgia, abdominal pain, renal involvement.
- Platelet count is typically normal (non-thrombocytopenic purpura pattern).
- Intussusception and nephritic complications are key monitoring risks.

## Behcet and mixed cryoglobulinemia
- Behcet: recurrent oral/genital ulcers with uveitis and thrombotic tendency.
- HCV-associated mixed cryoglobulinemia: purpura/weakness/arthralgia with low complement profile.

# PMR, Inflammatory Myopathy, MG, and Lambert-Eaton
## PMR
- Proximal pain/stiffness in older adults with elevated ESR/CRP and normal CK.
- Distinguish from true myopathic weakness.

## Inflammatory myopathies
- Proximal painless weakness with CK elevation.
- Dermatomyositis has characteristic rash features (heliotrope/Gottron) and should trigger malignancy screening.
- Autoantibody context includes anti-Jo-1 and other myositis panels when clinically indicated.

## Myasthenia gravis
- Fluctuating fatigable weakness (ocular/bulbar patterns prominent).
- Confirm with antibody/electrophysiologic strategies; evaluate thymic pathology with chest imaging.
- Crisis requires airway-focused critical care and rapid immunomodulatory therapy.
- Avoid medication triggers that worsen neuromuscular transmission (for example certain antibiotics/magnesium contexts).

## Lambert-Eaton
- Presynaptic disorder often linked to small-cell lung cancer with facilitation pattern (strength improves with repeated use).

# Rapid Recap: Vasculitis/Myopathy High-Yield
| Condition | Signature clue | Critical action |
| --- | --- | --- |
| GCA | jaw claudication ± visual warning | immediate steroids before biopsy delay |
| Kawasaki | fever >=5 days with mucocutaneous pattern | IVIG + aspirin and coronary follow-up |
| PAN | medium-vessel ischemic disease with lung sparing | angiographic/etiologic workup (including hepatitis context) |
| GPA | sinus-lung-kidney involvement | ANCA-supported systemic vasculitis pathway |
| HSP | pediatric palpable purpura + GI/joint/renal signs | monitor for intussusception and renal injury |
| PMR | pain/stiffness with high ESR but normal CK | low-dose glucocorticoid-responsive syndrome |
| Dermatomyositis | proximal weakness + characteristic rash | malignancy screening integration |
| MG | fatigable ocular/bulbar weakness | thymoma evaluation + crisis vigilance |
| LEMS | weakness improves with use | evaluate for small-cell lung malignancy |

# Pediatric Orthopedics: Limping Child and JIA
## Age-based limping-child approach
- Adolescents: SCFE (often obese; knee pain can be referred from hip).
- Age 4-10: Legg-Calve-Perthes disease pattern.
- Infants: developmental dysplasia screening branch.
- Toddlers with fever/non-weight-bearing: septic arthritis risk branch.

## Core map
```
Pediatric orthopedics
├── Hip emergencies and developmental disorders (SCFE, LCP, DDH)
├── Septic arthritis vs transient synovitis
└── Juvenile idiopathic arthritis subtypes/complications
```

## Key management anchors
- SCFE: urgent non-weight-bearing and operative fixation.
- DDH: age-specific imaging (US early, X-ray later) and harness-based early treatment.
- Septic hip suspicion (Kocher-style high score): urgent aspiration/drainage + antibiotics.

## JIA subtype table
| Subtype | Typical pattern | Critical monitoring point |
| --- | --- | --- |
| Systemic | quotidian fever + inflammatory systemic features | monitor for macrophage activation/inflammatory complications |
| Oligoarticular | <5 joints, often large-joint involvement | regular slit-lamp exams for silent uveitis |
| Polyarticular | >=5 joints, RA-like pattern | sustained disease-control strategy and growth/function follow-up |

# Pediatric Alignment, Foot, and Spine Developmental Patterns
## Physiologic alignment timeline
- Early genu varum may be physiologic, transitions toward valgum then normal alignment with growth.
- Red flags (asymmetry/severe persistence/systemic signs) suggest pathologic processes (for example Blount/rickets patterns).

## Intoeing sources
| Source | Typical age pattern | Clinical behavior |
| --- | --- | --- |
| Metatarsus adductus | infancy | flexible forms often resolve; rigid forms may require casting |
| Internal tibial torsion | toddler | usually improves with growth |
| Femoral anteversion | preschool age | often resolves gradually; W-sitting pattern common |

## Clubfoot
- Rigid equinovarus deformity needs early Ponseti serial casting.

## Other pediatric pearls
- Toddler’s fracture can be radiographically occult early and may be treated with immobilization based on exam suspicion.
- Growing pains are bilateral nocturnal pain with normal daytime exam; unilateral daytime limp requires broader workup.
- Congenital muscular torticollis improves with stretching in many cases.
- Scoliosis screening uses forward-bend asymmetry and Cobb-angle based follow-up.
